thread.title: Utah basketball notebook: Krystkowiak downplays Utes' third-place finish in Pac-12 preseason media poll

author: Dirk Facer
title: Utah basketball notebook: Krystkowiak downplays Utes' third-place finish in Pac-12 preseason media poll
text:
Utah basketball coach Larry Krystkowiak didn’t have much to say about this year’s Pac-12 preseason media poll. The Utes were picked to finish third behind Arizona and California.
More Coverage Utah's rise to prominence doesn't surprise Pac-12 coaches USA Today Top 25 preseason poll 
The top 25 teams in the USA Today men's preseason college basketball poll, with first-place votes in parentheses, final 2014-15 records, points based on 25 points for a first-place vote through one point for a 25th-place vote and final 2014-15 ranking:
Record Pts Pvs 1. North Carolina (12) 26-12 749 12 1. Kentucky (11) 38-1 749 3 3. Maryland (5) 28-7 723 16 4. Duke (3) 35-4 686 1 5. Kansas (1) 27-9 675 17 6. Virginia 30-4 667 8 7. Iowa State 25-9 541 19 8. Oklahoma 24-11 520 13 9. Villanova 33-3 498 9 10. Arizona 34-4 477 4 11. Gonzaga 35-3 468 6 12. Wichita State 30-5 461 11 13. Michigan State 27-12 386 7 14. California 18-15 350 - 15. Indiana 20-14 312 - 16. Utah 26-9 250 15 17. Wisconsin 36-4 181 2 18. Notre Dame 32-6 172 5 19. LSU 22-11 163 - 20. Vanderbilt 21-14 153 - 21. Baylor 24-10 145 21 22. Butler 23-11 132 23 23. West Virginia 25-10 125 18 24. Connecticut 20-15 110 - 24. Purdue 21-13 110 - Others receiving votes: Michigan 108, Louisville 93, Texas A&M 58, UCLA 48, Georgetown 45, Cincinnati 43, North Carolina State 36, Oregon 33, Texas 29, Florida State 25, Xavier 25, Miami 11, San Diego State 10, Iowa 8, Boise State 5, Davidson 5, Providence 5, Belmont 2, Ohio State 2, Stephen F. Austin 2, Dayton 1, Marquette 1, Old Dominion 1, Tulsa 1.
SAN FRANCISCO — Utah basketball coach Larry Krystkowiak didn’t have much to say about this year’s Pac-12 preseason media poll. The Utes were picked to finish third behind Arizona and California.
“Not much has ever changed,” said Krystkowiak, who explained that such predictions have never meant anything to him. “You’re never as good as you think you are and you’re never as bad as you think you are.”
Senior guard Brandon Taylor, who also represented the Utes at Thursday’s conference media day at the Pac-12 Networks studios, didn’t put much stock in the preseason poll, either.
“You don’t really pay attention to those. It’s almost like how can you really sit here and make a prediction? That’s what it’s going to be, you know?” Taylor said. “But it is what it is. We’ve never been the type of team to even pay attention. I mean it’s cool to be in the top three or four in what people’s opinions are, but we really don’t care what someone’s opinion is — no disrespect to anybody. It’s just we’re not too into what people think or anything like that.”
Utah was among five teams that picked up first-place votes. The Utes, who are coming off a 26-9 season and a Sweet 16 appearance, were the top choice of seven of the 36 voters. Arizona and California received 18 and nine, respectively. Oregon and UCLA each had a single vote.
The Ducks and Bruins were picked fourth and fifth overall in the poll and were followed in order by Oregon State, Colorado, Arizona State, Stanford, USC, Washington and Washington State.
Although Taylor downplayed the significance of the poll, he didn’t dismiss the big picture.
“You’re going to respect us, though. You’re going to respect us. That’s for sure,” he said. “You’re going to respect us and we’re going to go out there and make you respect us.”

PAYTON’S PLACE: Before starring at Oregon State, guard Gary Payton II excelled at Salt Lake Community College.
“I give all the credit to Salt Lake and coach Todd Phillips and coach Paul Marble up there,” Payton said. “They really taught me a lot about the game.”
Payton added that the speed and the way they play at SLCC really made his transition to the Pac-12 easier. As for how he didn’t land at Utah, Payton said it was more about “finding the right spot” for himself.
And that, as it turned out, is following in his father’s footsteps with the Beavers in Corvallis.
SPECIAL EXPERIENCE: Taylor enjoyed being Utah’s player representative at Pac-12 Media Day.
“It’s humbling. Especially just coming from where I come from,” Taylor said. “Like I’ve never been a part of anything like this and it’s special. I feel special.”
